entry.title: Do Transformers Really Perform Bad for Graph Representation?
Transformer for Graphsï¼šAn Overview from Architecture Perspective
entry.content:
1 ğŸ“‘Metadata

æ‘˜è¦ - Recently, Transformer model, which has achieved great successin many artiï¬cial intelligence ï¬elds, has demonstrated its greatpotential in modeling graph-structured data. Till now, a great varietyof Transformers has been proposed to adapt to the graph-structured data.However, a comprehensive literature review and systematical evaluationof these Transformer variants for graphs are still unavailable. It'simperative to sort out the existing Transformer models for graphs andsystematically investigate their effectiveness on various graph tasks.In this survey, we provide a comprehensive review of various GraphTransformer models from the architectural design perspective. We ï¬rstdisassemble the existing models and conclude three typical ways toincorporate the graph information into the vanilla Transformer: 1) GNNsas Auxiliary Modules, 2) Improved Positional Embedding from Graphs, and3) Improved Attention Matrix from Graphs. Furthermore, we implement therepresentative components in three groups and conduct a comprehensivecomparison on various kinds of famous graph data benchmarks toinvestigate the real performance gain of each component. Our experimentsconï¬rm the beneï¬ts of current graph-speciï¬c modules on Transformer andreveal their advantages on different kinds of graph tasks.

2 ğŸ’¡Note

2.1 è®ºæ–‡è¯•å›¾è§£å†³ä»€ä¹ˆé—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

To sort out the existing Transformer models for graphs andsystematically investigate their effectiveness on various graphtasks.

2.2 è¿™æ˜¯å¦æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

Yes, a comprehensive literature review and systematical evaluation ofthese Transformer variants for graphs are still unavailable.

2.3è¿™ç¯‡æ–‡ç« è¦éªŒè¯ä¸€ä¸ªä»€ä¹ˆç§‘å­¦å‡è®¾ï¼Ÿ

The benefits of current graph-specific modules on Transformer andreveal their advantages on different kinds of graph tasks: 1. Currentmodels incorporating the graph information can improve the performanceof Transformer on both graph-level and node-level tasks. 2. UtilizingGNN as auxiliary modules and improving attention matrix from graphsgenerally contributes more performance gains than encoding graphs intopositional embeddings. 3. The performance gain on graph-level tasks ismore significant than that on node-level tasks. 4. Different kinds ofgraph tasks enjoy different group of models.

2.4æœ‰å“ªäº›ç›¸å…³ç ”ç©¶ï¼Ÿå¦‚ä½•å½’ç±»ï¼Ÿè°æ˜¯è¿™ä¸€è¯¾é¢˜åœ¨é¢†åŸŸå†…å€¼å¾—å…³æ³¨çš„ç ”ç©¶å‘˜ï¼Ÿ

  1. Limitations of GNN based on the [[message passing]] paradigm:
    1. Expressive power bounded by WL isomorphism hierarchy.
    2. [[over-smoothing]] problem due to repeated local aggregation.
    3. [[over-squashing]] problem due to the exponential computation costwith the increase of model depth.
  2. Three typical ways to incorporate the graph information into thevanilla Transformer:
    1. GNNs as Auxiliary Modules:
      1. Build Transformer blocks on top of GNN blocks;
      2. Stack GNN blocks and Transformer blocks in each layer;
      3. Parallel GNN blocks and Transformer blocks in each layer.
    2. Improved Positional Embedding from Graphs.
      1. Compress the graph structure into positional embedding vectors andadd them to the input before it is fed to the vanilla Transformermodel.
    3. Improved Attention Matrices from Graphs.
      1. Inject graph priors into the attention computation via graph biasterms;
      2. Restrict a node only attending to local neighbors in the graph.

2.5ğŸ”´è®ºæ–‡ä¸­æåˆ°çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆä¹‹å…³é”®æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Ÿ

  • Standard Transformer considers the input tokens as a fully-connectedgraph, which is agnostic to the intrinsic graph structure among thedata.
  • Motivation: How to be aware of topological structures?

2.5.1 GNNs asAuxiliary Modules in Transformer

  1. According to the relative position between GNN layers andTransformer layers:
    1. Building Transformer blocks on top of GNN blocks .
        1. Using Transformer to empower the model global reasoningcapability.
      2. Grover
        1. Using two GTransformer modules to represent node-level features andedge-level features respectively.
        2. Inputs are fed into a tailored GNN of each GTransformer to extractvectors as Q, K, V, followed by standard multi-head attentionblocks.
      3. GraphiT
        1. Adopting one Graph Convolutional Kernel Network (GCKN) to produce astructure-aware representation from original features
        2. Concatenate them as the input of Transformer architecture.
    2. Alternately stacking GNN blocks and Transformer blocks.
      1. Mesh Graphormer
        1. Stacking a Graph Residual Block (GRB) on a multi-head self-attentionlayer as a Transformer block to model both local and globalinteractions
    3. Parallelizing GNN blocks and Transformer blocks.
      1. Graph-BERT
        1. Utilizing a graph residual term in each attention layer

2.5.2 ImprovedPositional Embeddings from Graphs

Combining GNNs and Transformer requires heavy hype-parametersearching.

Compress the graph structure into positional embedding (PE) vectorsand add them to the input before it is fed to the actual Transformermodel:

  1. Compress the adjacent matrix into dense positional embeddings
    1. Laplacian eigenvectorsï¼ˆuse eigenvectors of the smallest non-trivial eigenvalues as PEï¼‰:
    2. SVD vectors (use the largest singular values and corresponding left and right singular vectors):
  2. Heuristic methods
    1. Degree centrality:
    2. WL-PE: Representing different codes labeled by the Weisfeiler-Lehmanalgorithm.
    3. Hop based PE
    4. Intimacy based PE
    5. Learned PE: Utilizing the full Laplacian spectrum to learn theposition of each node in a given graph
  3. ...

2.5.3 ImprovedAttention Matrices from Graphs

Compressing graph structure into fixed-sized PE vectors suffers frominformation loss.

To improve the attention matrix computation based on graphinformation: 1. Restricting anode only attending to local node neighbors in the graph: -Extension 1. Encoding edge features: 2. Masking the attentionmatrices of different heads with different graph priors 3. Extending theadjacent matrix to a kernel matrix: 2.Adding soft graph bias to attention scores: 1. Graphormer: SpatialEncoding mechanism 1. Consider a distance function , such as theshortest path distance (SPD). 2. Assign each feasible value of a learnable scale parameter as agraph bias term. 3. Update rule: 1. is the learnable scalar indexed by 2. To handlegraph structure with edge features: - - for eachordered node pair , search (one of) the shortest path from to - is the feature of the -th edge in - is the -th learnable weight embedding 2.Gophormer: proximity enhanced multi-head attention (PE-MHA) to encodemultihop graph information. 1. For each node pair , views of structural information isencoded as a proximity encoding vector 2. Updaterule: - is the learnable parametersthat compute the bias of structural information - The proximity encodingis calculated by M structural encoding functions

2.6ä¸‹ä¸€æ­¥å‘¢ï¼Ÿæœ‰ä»€ä¹ˆå·¥ä½œå¯ä»¥ç»§ç»­æ·±å…¥ï¼Ÿ

  1. New paradigm of incorporating the graph and the Transformer.
  2. Extending to other kinds of graphs.
  3. Extending to large-scale graphs

entry.title: Representing Long-Range Context for Graph Neural Networks with Global Attention
entry.content:
1 ğŸ“‘Metadata

[!abstract] æ‘˜è¦
Graph neural networks are powerful architectures for structureddatasets. However, current methods struggle to represent long-rangedependencies. Scaling the depth or width of GNNs is insufficient tobroaden receptive fields as larger GNNs encounter optimizationinstabilities such as vanishing gradients and representationoversmoothing, while pooling-based approaches have yet to become asuniversally useful as in computer vision. In this work, we propose theuse of Transformer-based self-attention to learn long-range pairwiserelationships, with a novel "readout" mechanism to obtain a global graphembedding. Inspired by recent computer vision results that findposition-invariant attention performant in learning long-rangerelationships, our method, which we call GraphTrans, applies apermutation-invariant Transformer module after a standard GNN module.This simple architecture leads to state-of-the-art results on severalgraph classification tasks, outperforming methods that explicitly encodegraph structure. Our results suggest that purely-learning-basedapproaches without graph structure may be suitable for learninghigh-level, long-range relationships on graphs.

[!summary] ç»“è®º
We proposed GraphTrans, a simple yet powerful framework for learninglong-range relationships with GNNs. Leveraging recent results thatsuggest structural priors may be unnecessary or even counterproductivefor high-level, long-range relationships, we augment standard GNN layerstacks with a subsequent permutation-invariant Transformer module. TheTransformer module acts as a novel GNN "readout" module, simultaneouslyallowing the learning of pairwise interactions between graph nodes andsummarizing them into a special token's embedding as is done in commonNLP applications of Transformers. This simple framework leads tosurprising improvements upon the state of the art in several graphclassification tasks across program analysis, molecules and proteinassociation networks. In some cases, GraphTrans outperforms methods thatattempt to encode domain-specific structural information. Overall,GraphTrans presents a simple yet general approach to improve long-rangegraph classification; next directions include applications to node andedge classification tasks as well as further scalability improvements ofthe Transformer to large graphs.

2 ğŸ’¡Note

2.1 è®ºæ–‡è¯•å›¾è§£å†³ä»€ä¹ˆé—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

Current GNNs struggle to represent long-range dependencies.

2.2 è¿™æ˜¯å¦æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

The issue of transformers on graphs has been explored before.

2.3è¿™ç¯‡æ–‡ç« è¦éªŒè¯ä¸€ä¸ªä»€ä¹ˆç§‘å­¦å‡è®¾ï¼Ÿ

Adding a Transformer subnetwork on top of a standard GNN layer stackcan obtain SOTA results.

2.4æœ‰å“ªäº›ç›¸å…³ç ”ç©¶ï¼Ÿå¦‚ä½•å½’ç±»ï¼Ÿè°æ˜¯è¿™ä¸€è¯¾é¢˜åœ¨é¢†åŸŸå†…å€¼å¾—å…³æ³¨çš„ç ”ç©¶å‘˜ï¼Ÿ

2.4.1 Graph Classification

  1. Pooling operation:
    1. Global: reducing a set of node encodings to a single graph encoding.
      1. Non-learned mean or max-pooling over nodes
      2. the "virtual node" approach
    2. Local: collapsing subsets of nodes to create a coarser graph.
      1. Learned pooling schemes
      2. Non-learned pooling methods based on classic graph coarseningschemes
  2. Notable work
    1. DAGNN (Directed Acyclic Graph Neural Network)

2.4.2 Transformers on Graphs

  1. Introducing GNN layers to let nodes attend to other nodes in somesurrounding neighborhood via Transformer-style attention.
  2. Learning long-range dependencies without over smoothing: allowingnodes to attend to more than just the one-hop neighborhood.
    1. Take the attended neighborhood radius as a tuning parameter.
    2. Sample neighborhoods of random size during training andinference.
  3. Global average pooling over the nodes.
  4. Positional encodings.

2.4.3 Efficient Transformers

  1. Less FLOPs.
  2. Less computation and memory complexity.
  3. Neural architecture search (NAS)

2.5ğŸ”´è®ºæ–‡ä¸­æåˆ°çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆä¹‹å…³é”®æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Ÿ

2.5.1Motivation: Modeling Long-Range Pairwise Interactions

  1. Attempting for long-range learning on graphs have not yet led toperformance increase.
    1. Stacking GNN layers
    2. Hierarchical pooling
  2. Expanding the receptive field of a single GNN layer beyond a one-hopneighborhood is not scalable.
  3. For CNN:
    1. Attention layers can learn to reproduce the strong relationalinductive biases induced by local convolutions.
    2. While strong relational inductive biases are helpful for learninglocal, short-range correlations, for long-range correlations lessstructured modules may be preferred.
  4. GraphTrans:
    1. Long-range relationships are important.
    2. Using GNN as a backbone + Transformer to learn long-rangedependencies with no graph spatial priors.

entry.title: PRODIGYï¼šEnabling In-context Learning Over Graphs
entry.content:
1 ğŸ“‘Metadata

æ‘˜è¦
[[In-context learning]] is the ability of a pretrained model to adapt tonovel and diverse downstream tasks by conditioning on prompt examples,without optimizing any parameters. While large language models havedemonstrated this ability, how in-context learning could be performedover graphs is unexplored. In this paper, we developPretraining OverDiverse In-ContextGraph Systems (PRODIGY), the firstpretraining framework that enables in-context learning over graphs. Thekey idea of our framework is to formulate in-context learning overgraphs with a novel prompt graph representation, which connects promptexamples and queries. We then propose a graph neural networkarchitecture over the prompt graph and a corresponding family ofin-context pretraining objectives. With PRODIGY, the pretrained modelcan directly perform novel downstream classification tasks on unseengraphs via in-context learning. We provide empirical evidence of theeffectiveness of our framework by showcasing its strong in-contextlearning performance on tasks involving citation networks and knowledgegraphs. Our approach outperforms the in-context learning accuracy ofcontrastive pretraining baselines with hard-coded adaptation by 18% onaverage across all setups. Moreover, it also outperforms standardfinetuning with limited data by 33% on average with in-contextlearning.

ç»“è®º
We introduce PRODIGY, the first framework that enables in-contextlearning on graphs. A model that is pretrained using PRODIGY canseamlessly execute a new classification task over new graphs representedby prompt graph. It markedly surpasses the performance of other baselinemodels with in-context learning, even those that employ finetuning, inboth the node and edge classification tasks.

2 ğŸ’¡Note

2.1 è®ºæ–‡è¯•å›¾è§£å†³ä»€ä¹ˆé—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

  1. [[In-context learning]] over graphs.
    1. How to formulate and represent node-, edgeand graph-level tasks overgraphs with a unified task representation that allows the model to solvediverse tasks without the need for retraining or parameter tuning?--> what is an analog of natural language prompting for graph machinelearning tasks?
    2. How to design model architecture and pre-training objectives thatenable models to achieve in-context learning capability across diversetasks and diverse graphs in the unified task representation? --> Howto tackle the more difficult setting of generalizing across the graphsand tasks without fine-tuning?

2.2 è¿™æ˜¯å¦æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

Yes, this problem is unexplored.

2.3è¿™ç¯‡æ–‡ç« è¦éªŒè¯ä¸€ä¸ªä»€ä¹ˆç§‘å­¦å‡è®¾ï¼Ÿ

With the proposed pre-training framework, named PRODIGY, thepre-trained model can directly perform novel downstream classificationtasks on unseen graphs via [[In-context learning]].

2.4æœ‰å“ªäº›ç›¸å…³ç ”ç©¶ï¼Ÿå¦‚ä½•å½’ç±»ï¼Ÿè°æ˜¯è¿™ä¸€è¯¾é¢˜åœ¨é¢†åŸŸå†…å€¼å¾—å…³æ³¨çš„ç ”ç©¶å‘˜ï¼Ÿ

2.4.1 In-contextLearning of Large Language Models

Pre-trained large language models can make predictions for diversedownstream tasks directly by prompting with a few examples ofthe task or more generally any textual instructions.

2.4.2 Pre-training on Graphs

  1. Existing works on pre-training graphs all follow the generalparadigm of learning a good graph encoder that can perform pre-trainingtasks.
  2. To adapt to any downstream tasks, it then requiresfine-tuning a classification head on top of the encoderwith large amount of task specific data for each downstream task.

2.4.3 Meta Learning on Graphs

  1. Existing meta-learning methods are only designed and tested forgeneralizing across different tasks on the same graph: the methods aretrained on a set of training tasks on a graph, then tested over adisjoint but similar set of test tasks over the same graph.
  2. Exhibit optimal performance only when trained on similarcurated tasks.

2.5ğŸ”´è®ºæ–‡ä¸­æåˆ°çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆä¹‹å…³é”®æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Ÿ

[! Summary] Contribution
1. Prompt Graph: an in-context graph taskrepresentation 2. PRODIGY: a framework for pre-training an in-contextlearner over prompt graphs.

2.5.1 In-context Learning overGraphs

2.5.1.1 Classification Tasksover Graphs

A unified formulation, the space of the input consists of graphs, : 1. Node classification: and 2. Edgeclassification: and 3. Subgraphclassification 4. Graph classification

2.5.1.2 Few-shot Prompting

[[å°‘æ ·æœ¬å­¦ä¹ ]]

  1. For a -shot prompt with adownstream -way classificationtasks with classes:
    1. a small number of input-label pairs as prompt examples of thetask specification --> input-label pairs with label .
    2. a set of queries that we want to predict labels for.
  2. Since all input datapoints are nodes/edges/subgraphs from the largersource graph , thisgraph contains critical information and provides contexts for theinputs.
    • We also need to include the source graph in the prompt.
  3. The pre-trained model should be able to directly output thepredicted labels for each datapoint in via in-context learning.

2.5.1.3 Prompt GraphRepresentation

A prompt graph is composed of data graphs and a task graph.

[!Question] å»ºæ¨¡ä¸ºäºŒéƒ¨å›¾ï¼Ÿ

  1. Data graph
    1. To gather more information about the from the source graph without having to representthe entire source graph explicitly.
    2. Perform contextualization of each datapoint in and in the source graph to form data graphs.
      1. Explicitly retrieving subgraphs
      2. Implicitly using embedding-based methods
    3. Sample -hop neighborhood of in : Neighbor
  2. Task graph
    1. To better capture the connection and relationship among theinputs and the labels.
    2. Node:
      1. For each data graph , a data node represents each input.
      2. For each label, there is a label node .
      3. A task graph contains data nodes ( prompt examples and queries) and label nodes.
    3. Edge:
      1. For the query set, each query data node will be connected to all thelabel nodes.
      2. For the prompt examples, we connect each data node to all the labelnodes, where the edge with the true labels is marked as while the others are marked as .

2.5.2 Pre-trainingto Enable In-context Learning

Assume access to a pre-training graph that isindependent of the source graph for the downstream task.

2.5.2.1 MessagePassing Architecture over Prompt Graph

  1. Data graph Message Passing
    1. Learn node representation :
    2. Read out a single embedding :
      1. For node classification --> :
      2. For link prediction:
  2. Task graph Message Passing
    1. The initial embedding of data node is .
    2. The embedding of label node can either be initialized withrandom Gaussian or additional information available about thelabels.
    3. Each edge also has two binary features that indicate
      1. whether the edge comes from an example or a query
      2. the edge type of or .
    4. Attention-based GNN
  3. Prediction Read Out
    • Readout the classification logits by taking cosine similarity betweeneach pair of query graph representation and label representation

2.5.2.2 In-contextPre-training Objectives

To pretrain the graph model using a large pretraining graph independent of the downstream task graph

entry.title: Graph Inductive Biases in Transformers without Message Passing
entry.content:
1 ğŸ“‘Metadata

æ‘˜è¦

Transformers for graph data are increasingly widely studied andsuccessful in numerous learning tasks. Graph [[inductive biases]] arecrucial for Graph Transformers, and previous works incorporate themusing message-passing modules and/or positional encodings. However,Graph Transformers that use message-passing inherit known issues ofmessage-passing, and differ significantly from Transformers used inother domains, thus making transfer of research advances more difficult.On the other hand, Graph Transformers without message-passing oftenperform poorly on smaller datasets, where inductive biases are moreimportant. To bridge this gap, we propose the Graph Inductive biasTransformer (GRIT) â€” a new Graph Transformer that incorporates graphinductive biases without using message passing. GRIT is based on severalarchitectural changes that are each theoretically and empiricallyjustified, including: learned relative positional encodings initializedwith random walk probabilities, a flexible attention mechanism thatupdates node and node-pair representations, and injection of degreeinformation in each layer. We prove that GRIT is expressive â€” it canexpress shortest path distances and various graph propagation matrices.GRIT achieves state-of-the-art empirical performance across a variety ofgraph datasets, thus showing the power that Graph Transformers withoutmessage-passing can deliver.

ç»“è®º
Observing the performance gap of Graph Transformers between small andlarge-scale datasets, we argue for the importance of graph inductivebiases in Graph Transformers. Motivated by promoting inductive biases inGraph Transformers without message-passing, we propose GRIT, based onthree theoretically and empirically motivated design choices forincorporating graph inductive biases. Our learned relative positionalencodings initialized with RRWP along with our flexible attentionmechanism allow for an expressive model that can provably captureshortest path distances and general families of graph propagations.Theoretical results show that the RRWP initialization is strictly moreexpressive than shortest path distances when used in the GD-WL graphisomorphism test (Zhang et al., 2023), and a synthetic experiment showsthat our flexible attention mechanism is indeed able to learn graphpropagation matrices that other Graph Transformers are not as capable oflearning. Our GRIT model achieves state-of-the-art performance across awide range of graph datasets, showing that data complexity can beimproved for Graph Transformers without integrating localmessage-passing modules. Nonetheless, GRIT is not the final chapter forgraph inductive biases in Transformers; future work can addresslimitations of our work, such as GRIT's scaling for updating pairrepresentations, and lack of upper bounds on expressive power.

2 ğŸ’¡Note

2.1 è®ºæ–‡è¯•å›¾è§£å†³ä»€ä¹ˆé—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

  1. Graph inductive biases in graph transformer.
    1. Graph Transformers that use message-passing inherit known issues ofmessage-passing, and differ significantly from Transformers used inother domainsã€‚
    2. Graph Transformers without message-passing often perform poorly onsmaller datasets, where inductive biases are more important.

2.2 è¿™æ˜¯å¦æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

Yes, the problem of graph inductive biases in graph transformers hasnot been explored previously.

2.3è¿™ç¯‡æ–‡ç« è¦éªŒè¯ä¸€ä¸ªä»€ä¹ˆç§‘å­¦å‡è®¾ï¼Ÿ

The proposed Graph Inductive bias Transformer (GRIT), a new GraphTransformer that incorporates graph inductive biases without usingmessage passing, bridges the performance gap in whichmessage-passing-based methods do not perform as well in largedatasets, and non-message-passing Transformers do notperform as well in small datasets.

2.4æœ‰å“ªäº›ç›¸å…³ç ”ç©¶ï¼Ÿå¦‚ä½•å½’ç±»ï¼Ÿè°æ˜¯è¿™ä¸€è¯¾é¢˜åœ¨é¢†åŸŸå†…å€¼å¾—å…³æ³¨çš„ç ”ç©¶å‘˜ï¼Ÿ

2.4.1 Transformers forEuclidean Domains

  1. Suffer from a lack of inductive bias compared to RNNs and CNNs.
  2. Require a large amount of training data to perform well.

2.4.2Positional Encoding and Structural Encoding for Graphs

  1. Positional Encoding (PE) & Structural Encoding (SE)
  2. To enhance both MPNNs and Graph Transformers
    1. To capture various types of graph features
      • Shortest-path distances
      • Identity-awareness
      • Spectral information
  3. Note: PE and SE are used interchangeably.

2.4.3 GraphTransformers with Message-Passing

  1. Transformer with Laplacian Positional Encoding (LapPE).
  2. SAN
    1. Use both sparse and global attention mechanism at each layer.
    2. Introduce an extra transformer to encode LapPE.
  3. SignNet
    1. Specialized symmetry-invariant encoder for LapPE.
    2. Use message-passing modules to process Laplacian eigenvectors.
  4. RWSE
    1. Use random walk structural encodings.
    2. Integrate message-passing modules.

2.4.4 GraphTransformers without Message-Passing

  1. Use relative positional encodings for each pair of nodes.
    1. SPDPE
      1. Shortest-path distance positional encodings.
    2. Generalized-Distance Transformers
      1. Resistance distances.
    3. Perform well on large datasets but worse on smaller ones, comparedto hybrid Graph Transformers and MPNNs.
      1. Due to the lack of sufficient inductive bias, they are not ascapable in enabling attention mechanisms to perform localmessage-passing when necessary.
  2. TokenGT
    1. View both nodes and edges as tokens, and uses LapPE or orthogonalrandom features.
  3. Relational Transformer
    1. Update both node and edge tokens.
  4. EGT
    1. Use SVD-based PE instead of LapPE for directed graphs.
  5. Introduce PE based on heat kernels and other graph kernels.

2.5ğŸ”´è®ºæ–‡ä¸­æåˆ°çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆä¹‹å…³é”®æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Ÿ

2.5.1 Learned RandomWalk Relative Encodings

  1. As the message-passing module is removed, the positional encodingmust adequately capture the graph structure.
  2. RRWP: Relative RandomWalk Probabilities initial positionalencoding
      2. is the probability thati hops to j in one step of a simple random walk.
      3. is the identity matrix
      4. Diagonal canadditionally be utilized as an initial node-level structural encoding--> Random Walk Structural Encodings (RWSE)
      5. controls the maximum lengthof random walks considered.
    2. can be updated by anelement-wise to get new relative positional encodings
      1. Expressive power
      2. Providing a useful inductive bias

2.5.2Flexible Attention Mechanism with Absolute and RelativeRepresentations

  1. Most current designs of the self-attention mechanism are based onnode-token-level PE and node-token-levelrepresentations, but this does not fully capture therelative positional information between pairs ofnodes.
  2. In each transformer layer, node representations and node-pair representations are both updated:
    1. Initialize these using the initial node features and RRWP positionalencodings.
      1. .
      2. .
      3. Set if there is no observed edge from i to jin the original graph.
    2. Compute the attention score.
      1. is a non-linearactivation (ReLU by default)
      2. and are learnable weight matrices;
      3. indicates elementwisemultiplication;
      4. is thesigned-square-root, which stabilizes training by reducing the magnitudeof large inputs.
    3. Can be extended to multiple heads (say, heads) by assigning different weightmatrices for different heads.

2.5.3 Injecting DegreeInformation

  1. Attention mechanisms are innately invariant to node degrees,analogously to mean-aggregation; this introduces extra ambiguities andhence reduces expressive power in processing graph-structured data.
  2. Inject degree information into the node representations:
    1. is the degree of node , and are learnable weights.
    2. Follow this with a standard feed-forward network (FFN) to update thenode representations.
    3. Apply batch normalization instead of the standard layernormalization

  2. 2 benchmarks from the recently developed Long-Range GraphBenchmark.

entry.title: Recipe for a General, Powerful, Scalable Graph Transformer
entry.content:
1 ğŸ“‘Metadata

æ‘˜è¦

We propose a recipe on how to build a general, powerful, scalable(GPS) graph Transformer with linear complexity and state-of-the-artresults on a diverse set of benchmarks. Graph Transformers (GTs) havegained popularity in the ï¬eld of graph representation learning with avariety of recent publications but they lack a common foundation aboutwhat constitutes a good positional or structural encoding, and whatdifferentiates them. In this paper, we summarize the different types ofencodings with a clearer deï¬nition and categorize them as being local,global or relative. The prior GTs are constrained to small graphs with afew hundred nodes, here we propose the ï¬rst architecture with acomplexity linear in the number of nodes and edges by decoupling the localreal-edge aggregation from the fully-connected Transformer. We arguethat this decoupling does not negatively affect the expressivity, withour architecture being a universal function approximator on graphs. OurGPS recipe consists of choosing 3 main ingredients: (i)positional/structural encoding, (ii) local message-passing mechanism,and (iii) global attention mechanism. We provide a modular frameworkGRAPHGPS1 that supports multiple types of encodings and that providesefï¬ciency and scalability both in small and large graphs. We test ourarchitecture on 16 benchmarks and show highly competitive results in allof them, show-casing the empirical beneï¬ts gained by the modularity andthe combination of different strategies.

2 ğŸ’¡Note

2.1 è®ºæ–‡è¯•å›¾è§£å†³ä»€ä¹ˆé—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

Graph Transformers (GTs) lack a common foundation about whatconstitutes a good positional or structural encoding, and whatdifferentiates them.

2.2 è¿™æ˜¯å¦æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Ÿ

The principled framework for designing GTs has not been exploredbefore.

2.3è¿™ç¯‡æ–‡ç« è¦éªŒè¯ä¸€ä¸ªä»€ä¹ˆç§‘å­¦å‡è®¾ï¼Ÿ

The Transformer, flexible message-passing, and rich positional andstructural encodings can all contribute to the success of GPS on a widevariety of benchmarks.

2.4æœ‰å“ªäº›ç›¸å…³ç ”ç©¶ï¼Ÿå¦‚ä½•å½’ç±»ï¼Ÿè°æ˜¯è¿™ä¸€è¯¾é¢˜åœ¨é¢†åŸŸå†…å€¼å¾—å…³æ³¨çš„ç ”ç©¶å‘˜ï¼Ÿ

2.4.1 Graph Transformers (GT)

  1. Expected to help alleviate the problems of over-smoothing andover-squashing in MPNNs.
  2. Fully-connected Graph Transformer
    • Use eigenvectors of the graph Laplacian as the node positionalencoding (PE).
  3. SAN
    1. Implement an invariant aggregation of Laplacian's eigenvectors forthe PE.
    2. Use conditional attention for real and virtual edges of agraph.
  4. Graphormer
    • Use pair-wise graph distances (or 3D distances) to define relativepositional encodings.
  5. GraphiT
    • Use relative PE derived from diffusion kernels to modulate theattention between nodes.
  6. GraphTrans: Hybrid architecture
    1. First use a stack of MPNN layers, before fully-connecting thegraph.
    2. SAT, EGT, GRPE

2.4.2 Positional andStructural Encodings

  1. Previous works
    1. Laplacian PE
    2. Shortest-path-distance
    3. Node degree centrality
    4. Kernel distance
    5. Random-walk SE
    6. Structural-aware
  2. Categorization
  3. PE/SE are:
    1. used as [[soft bias]], meaning they are simply provided as inputfeatures.
    2. used to direct the messages or create bridges between distantnodes.

2.4.3 Linear Transformers

  1. Quadratic complexity of attention in the original Transformerarchitecture.
  2. Language modeling:
    1. Linformer
    2. Reformer
    3. Longformer
    4. Performer
    5. BigBird
  3. Graph domain:
    1. Performer-style attention kernelization

2.5ğŸ”´è®ºæ–‡ä¸­æåˆ°çš„è§£å†³æ–¹æ¡ˆä¹‹å…³é”®æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Ÿ

[!Note] Modular GPS graph Transformer, with examples of PE and SE.Task specific layers for node/graph/edge-level predictions, such aspooling or output MLP, are omitted for simplicity.
1. Categorization of PE and SE; 2. How PE and SEincrease expressivity; 3. Hybrid MPNN+Transformer architecture.

2.5.1 ModularPositional and Structural Encodings

PE and SE are different yet complementary. 1. PE gives a notion ofdistance. 2. SE gives a notion of structural similarity. 3. Global--> a text 4. Local --> a sentence 5. Relative --> distancebetween two words 6. Node --> a word

2.5.1.1 What is PE and SE?

  1. Positional Encodings (PE)
    1. Providing an idea of the position in space of a given nodewithin the graph.
    2. Two close nodes within a graph or subgraph have close PE.
    3. Previous approach: Computing pair-wise distance between each pairsof nodes or their eigenvectors.
    4. Linear complexity PE should either be features of nodes or real edges of the graph.
      1. The eigenvectors of the graph Laplacian.
      2. Or their gradient.
  2. Structural Encodings (SE)
    1. Providing an embedding of the structure of graphs orsubgraphs to help increase the expressivity and the generalizability ofGNNs.
    2. Two nodes sharing similar subgraphs or two similar graphs have closeSE.
    3. Previous approach:
      1. Identifying pre-defined patterns in the graphs as one-hot encodings Requiring expertknowledge of graphs.
      2. Using diagonal of the m-steps random-walk matrix.
      3. Using the eigenvalues of the Laplacian.

2.5.1.2 Local

Used as node features.

  1. Local PE:
    • Allow a node to know its position and role within a local cluster ofnodes.
    • Within a cluster, the closer two nodes are to each other, the closertheir local PE will be.
  2. Local SE:
    • Allow a node to understand what sub-structures it is a part of.
    • The more similar the m-hop subgraphs around two nodes are, thecloser their local SE will be.

2.5.1.3 Global

Used as node or graph features.

  1. Global PE:
    • Allow a node to know its global position within a graph.
    • Within a graph, the closer two nodes are, the closer their global PEwill be.
  2. Global SE:
    • Provide the network with information about the global structure ofthe graph.
    • The more similar two graphs are, the closer their global SE willbe.

2.5.1.4 Relative

Used as edge features.

  1. Relative PE
    • Allow two nodes to understand their distances or directionalrelationships.
    • Edge embedding that is correlated to the distance given by anyglobal or local PE.
  2. Relative SE
    • Allow two nodes to understand how much their structure differ.
    • Edge embedding that is correlated to the difference between anylocal SE.

2.5.2 Why Do We Need PE and SEin MPNN?

  1. Equivalence between 1-WL test and MPNNs --> limitations ofexpressive power.
  2. Using PE and SE as soft biases.

2.5.2.1 1-Weisfeiler-Leman test(1-WL)

[!Note] About 1-Weisfeiler-Leman test (1-WL) 1. Iteratively updatingthe color of a node based on its 1-hop local neighborhood 2. Until aniteration when the node colors do not change change successively. 3. Thefinal histogram of the node colors determine whether the algorithmoutputs the two graphs to be â€˜non-isomorphicâ€™.

[!Note] About Expressive power of MPNNs. 1. The aggregation andupdate function in MPNNs are at most powerful as the hash function ofthe [[1-WL test]]. 2. GIN: Graph Isomorphism Network.

  1. Standard MPNNs are as expressive as the [[1-WL test]]ï¼Œfailing todistinguish non-isomorphic graphs under a 1-hop aggregation
  2. Local, global and relative PE/SE allow MPNNs to become moreexpressive than the 1-WL test.

2.5.2.2 Circular Skip Link (CSL)graph

  1. 1-WL cannot distinguish the two non-isomorphic graphs. -->Neither does MPNN.
    1. Using a global PE assigns each node a unique initial color and makesthe CSL graph-pair distinguishable.
    2. Using a local SE can successfully capture the difference in the skiplinks of the two graphs, resulting in their different nodecoloring.

2.5.2.3 The Decalin MolecularGraph

  1. 1-WL: The combination of the node colors of the node-sets willproduce the same embedding for the two links.

  2. Using local PE is noneffective.

  3. Using a distance-based relative PE on the edges or aneigenvector-based global PE would successfully differentiate theembeddings of the two links.

Proposition: there exists Positional Encodings (PE) and StructuralEncoding (SE) which MPNNs are not guaranteed to learn.

2.5.3 GPS Layer: anMPNN+Transformer Hybrid

2.5.3.1 Preventing earlysmoothing

  1. GraphTrans-style:
    • Using a few layers of MPNNs before the Transformer.
  2. Limitation:
    • Due to [[over-smoothing]], [[over-squashing]], and low expressivityagainst the WL-test, MPNNs irreparably fail to keep someinformation in the early stage.

2.5.3.2 Update function

[!Note] GPS layers

At each layer, the features are updated by aggregating the output ofan MPNN layer with that of a global attention layer.

The precise application of skip connections, dropout, and batchnormalization with learnable affine parameters:

2.5.3.3 Modularity,Scalability and Expressivity

  1. Modularity
    1. PE/SE types.
    2. The networks that processes those PE/SE.
    3. The MPNN layers.
    4. The global attention layers.
    5. The final task-specific prediction head.
    6. Other layers.
  2. Scalability
    1. The computational complexity is linear: .
      1. A linear Transformer with complexity.
      2. The complexity of an MPNN is
  3. Expressivity
    1. Does not lose edge information.
    2. A universal function approximator on graphs.

2.5.4 Theoretical Expressivity

2.5.4.1Preserving edge information in the Transformer layer

  1. Previous GTs:
    1. Graph Transformer, SAN and Graphormer: only use edge features tocondition the attention between node pairs.
    2. GraphiT: does not consider edge features at all.
    3. 2-step methods (GraphTrans and SAT): use edge features in the firstMPNN step --> [[over-smoothing]]
  2. GPS:
    1. One round of local neighborhood aggregation via an MPNN layer.
    2. Global self-attention mechanism.
      1. Explicitly depends on node features.
      2. Implicitly encodes edge information.
    3. Reduces the initial representation bottleneck.
    4. Enables iterative local and global interactions.

2.5.4.2 Universalfunction approximator on graphs

  1. Given the full set of Laplacian eigenvectors, GTs was a universalfunction approximator on graphs and could provide an approximatesolution to the isomorphism problem.
  2. More powerful than any WL isomorphism test given enoughparameters.

    1. Nowadays, watching TV is one of the most important children'sleisure activities.
    2. However, whether it brings more than good is a controversialissue.
    3. My view is that too much time spent on it surely has negativeimpacts on kids and parents should filter out the inappropriate programsand channels for them.
    4. First, it is obvious that, with the rapid development of science andtechnology, TV shows are designed so vivid and attractive that not onlykids but even adults are much easier to get addicted to them.
    5. This means that when children spend more time sitting in front ofscreen, they are isolated from the real world. They do not have enoughtime to socialize or to engage in outdoor activities which are crucialfor their for their physical growth.
    6. Also, their eyesight will be weakened by staring at the screen fortoo long.
    7. Moreover, questionable contents on TV will have negative effects onchildren since their minds are impressionable.
    8. For example, the fact that many developing countries including Chinalack a TV program rating system means that children are more easilyexposed to indecent TV scenes.
    9. So, TV is not always a good one in the sense that parents reallycannot control what comes on the screen.
    10. It is also true that there are many educational and inspirational TVshows, such as Disney cartoons which enable kids to have fun in thelearning process, facilitate their intellectual development and helpthem caring, sharing, courage, honesty and other virtues from an earlyage.
    11. These benefits of TV on a child's education cannot be denied.
    12. In sum, spending a long time watching TV is harmful and parentsshould either follow TV rating guidelines or carefully choose theprograms for children.

[!Note] é¢˜ç›®

These two bar graphs illustrates the changes of USAmarriage and divorce rates between 1970 and 2000, and the marital statusof adult Americans in two of the years.

According to the first graph, there were 2.5mmarriages in both 1970 and 1980, and then decreased gradually during thenext two decades, reaching to 2m in 2000. By comparison, the number ofdivorces first increased from 1m in 1970 to around 1.4m in 1980 and thenslowly declined back to 1m in 2000.

As can be seen from the second bar graph, thepercentage of married American adults dropped by more than 10%, from 70%in 1970 to less than 60% in 2000. Meanwhile, the percentage of adultAmerican who were never married increased from about 15% in 1970 to 20%in 2000, and despite still less than 10%, the proportion of divorcedadults significantly went up from 1970 to 2000. Moreover, the percentageof the widowed in 1970 and 2000 accounted for less than 10%respectively, and showed a slight drop.

Overall, it is clear that marital status of adultAmericans in 2000 was not as optimistic as that of three decadesago.

These graphs illustrate the change of people'seating habits between 1970 and 2000.

According to the four pie charts, the percentage ofthe family's food budget spent on restaurant meals steadilyincreased during this period. Just 10 percent of the foodbudget was spent on restaurant meals in 1970, and 15 percent in 1980.That percentage more than doubled in 1990, to 35 percent, and rose againin 2000 to 50 percent.

As can be seen from the following line graph,families ate the same number of meals at fast food and sit-downrestaurants, 20 meals in 1970. In 1980, families ate slightly morefrequently at sit-down restaurants. However, at the end of 1980's,the popularity of the fast food caught up with that of the sit-downrestaurants, and families ate about 40 meals at both fast food andsit-down restaurants per year. From then on, the number fast foodmeals increased much more dramatically to 90 meals in 2000, nearlydoubling the number of meals they ate at sit-downrestaurants.

Overall, it is clear that people spent more andmore money on restaurant meals and fast food became animportant option when families chose to eat out.

5.3.4 æ··åˆå›¾è¡¨

These two diagrams illustrate the main reasons ofland degradation in the world and its different impacts on three areasduring the 1990s.

According to the first pie chart, livestock'sover-grazing was the biggest factor leading to the barren land,accounting for the 35%. This was followed by deforestation andover-cultivation, representing 30% and 28% respectively. Otherunidentified reasons made up the left proportion, 7%collectively.

As can be seen from the second table whichhighlights the different situations in the three regions: NorthAmerica, Europe, and Oceania, Europe was affected most seriously and 23%of land there turned into less productive, largely caused bydeforestation (9.8%). Moreover, 13% of agricultural land in Oceaniabecame worse, mainly due to over-grazing which alone contributed11.3%. By comparison, the condition in North America wasmuch better and only 5% of total land degraded. Over-cultivation wasthe major trigger there, providing 3.3%.

Overall, it is clear that at least 93% of farmlanddegradation worldwide was related to human activities in 1990 s andalthough the dominant cause varies in different continents, Europesuffered most during that period.

    1. Nowadays, environmental protection is one of themost important challenges almost every country is facing.
    2. However, whether only governments and bigcorporations have the resources and capabilities to preserve ourenvironment is a controversial issue.
    3. My view is that every single citizen could alsomake a huge difference.
    4. First, it is obvious that humanactivities have had the greatest impact on the environment throughouthistory.
    5. This means that both environmental degradation andpreservation are the long-term process, and no single government or bigcompany can meet this challenge alone.
    6. So, whoever created the problem should solve it;environment protection needs every one of us to continuously participatein.
    7. Moreover, the public's wills and behaviors have acritical influence on government polices and company strategies.
    8. For example, if everyone say "no" to plasticshopping bags and paper cups, the companies that manufacture suchproducts will switch to [[environmentally-friendly]] substitutes inorder to survive in the market.
    9. That is not to say that governments and largecompanies can not positively contribute.
    10. Indeed, governments can enact laws and introduceprograms to raise the public's [[ecological footprint awareness]];companies can promote green products to change the public's consuminghabits.
    11. But they also need every citizen's appreciation andsupport to bring good results.
    12. In summary, no effort is too small whenwe are protecting the environment.
    13. Meanwhile, local authorities and organizations must[[shoulder]] their responsibility to develop a low carbon economy at themacro level.
    14. Only by doing so can we assure that we will hand thisbeautiful planet to our next generation, and the next generationthereafter.

    1. Nowadays, an increasing number of people are concernedabout animal protection and animal rights.
    2. However, whether we should utilize animals forhuman purposes has recently caused a heateddebate.
    3. In my view, it is acceptable to reasonably useanimals for the benefit of mankind and impossible to completely cut downthe human's reliance on animals.
    4. First, it is clear that human beings are standingat the top of the food chain of this planet.
    5. This means that mankind uses animals for its ownbenefit, which is consistent with natural law.
    6. So it is hard to say that we are doing wrong byexploiting animals for our interests.
    7. Moreover, it is unrealistic to ban using animalssince the history of human civilization is entwined with thehistory of the ways we have learned to manipulate animalresources.
    8. For example, we have raised cattle food, theoutcomes of animal experiments have saved many lives, and people haveeven kept pets to satisfy their psychological needs.
    9. If using animals were prohibited, we would firstly close thousandsof restaurants' franchises around the world and become vegetarians.
    10. This is not to say that it is always right forpeople to use animals for any purpose whatsoever.
    11. There are, of course, some behaviors that peoplehunt wild animals just for fun and kill rare animals for their expensivefurs, which are not only cruel and unnecessary, but actually againstlong-term interests of human race.
    12. Humans should shoulder their responsibilities of maintaining thediversity of wild animals and the balance of ecosystem.
    13. In sum, using animals rationally for the benefit ofhumans is justified.
    14. Meanwhile, some behaviors that are harmful to bothanimals and humans have to be prohibited.
    15. Only by doing so can we assure that our nextgeneration will also benefit from animal resource.

    1. Nowadays, the application of new technologies isone of the most important ways of making millionaires such as BillGates.
    2. However, whether the technology has also widenedthe gap between the rich and the poor is a controversialissue.
    3. My view is that the improper distribution of socialwealth, rather than an influx of modern technology, has caused such asocial problem.
    4. Firstly, it is obvious that the responsibilityfalls on the government as the one most capable and likely to solve anysocial issue and ensure social equality.
    5. This means that, in order to bridge this wealthgap, the most effective and direct method should be taxation leverage,by which the government can us the rich people's tax money to subsidizethe less fortunate.
    6. So, the technology should not become a scapegoat ofthis issue.
    7. Conversely, modern technologies indeed haveprovided great opportunities for the impoverished to go from rags toriches.
    8. For example, many people has become wealthy byopening their own online shops on e-commerce platforms.
    9. Compared with traditional companies that require large initialinvestment and higher operation cost, the Internet is a cheaper and moreaccessible platform for ordinary people to make a fortune.
    10. It is also true that poor countries are gettingpoorer due to the lack of creative technologies.
    11. Of course, this is a real phenomenon.
    12. But, the right solution for those nations is justto introduce advanced technologies to improve social productivity, whichis like the age-old chicken-or-egg question.
    13. In summary, modern technologies plays a key role infilling the gap between the rich and poor not only for individuals, butfor nations as well.
    14. Meanwhile, governments must [[shoulder]] theirresponsibility to ensure a fair distribution of wealth in society.
    15. Only by doing so can we believe that technologywill serve as a catalyst for creating social wealth.

    1. Nowadays, poverty is one of the most detrimentalproblems faced by many developing countries.
    2. However, which type of international aid is mosteffective for them is a controversial issue.
    3. In my view, what they need most is not financial aid or loans, butadvanced technologies and talents in certain key areas.
    4. Firstly, it is obvious that modern technologies andscientific advancement are the driving force behind rich nations.
    5. This is because hi-tech products, innovations, andgood management can greatly improve the productivity of a whole society,wealth is accumulated at a high speed.
    6. So, to help the poor, we had better give them toolsthat can make a fortune.
    7. Moreover, developed countries can not only sendteams of experts to poor nations to build roads, dams, factories andother infrastructure, but also train talents and experts for them.
    8. For example, rich countries can providescholarships or financial help to students from poorer regions, whichsome famous western universities are actually doing.
    9. It is also wiser way to deliver help.
    10. This is not to say that rich countries should notprovide aid in form of money in any case.
    11. Of course, money definitely can help a country outof many urgent problems.
    12. But we have to make sure that international fundsare spent where people really need it rather than filling the pockets oflocal corrupt politicians.
    13. In summary, there are some other types of aid richcountries may choose to offer more efficiently, for example, providingadvanced technologies and talents that can facilitate economic growthsustainably.
    14. From this sense, giving money to poor regions is not a direct aid,but an indirect form.

    1. Nowadays, advertising is a powerful marketing toolthat almost every company is utilizing.
    2. However, whether so many commercials have exertedmore positive or negative influence on people's lives is acontroversial issue.
    3. My view is that everyone as a customer should havea balanced understanding of ads.
    4. First, it is obvious that advertising bridges thedemand and supply in the market.
    5. This means that business ads on TV, radio andnewspaper provide useful and valuable information about a product orservice audiences, help them to compare qualities of different productsand choose the most cost-effective one.
    6. It is also an essential way for companies to promote their products,boost sales, make profits, and build brand images.
    7. Moreover, if ads are created to be memorable andthought-provoking, they can draw public's attention and change people'sattitudes and behaviors as well.
    8. For example, governments often disseminateimportant messages to community through public service advertising.
    9. It can raise the public's awareness, ranging from road safety topublic health, animal rights and environmental protection, which isdefinitely beneficial to the whole of society.
    10. It is also true that advertisements generally onlyclaims a product's advantages and the high cost of the ads is added tothe product's retail price, which is ultimately [[borne]] bycustomers.
    11. Of course, in order to entice consumer to purchasean item, some ads are even exaggerated and misleading.
    12. And more offensively, some advertising agencies illegally collectour personal information, then keep sending promotional ads throughannoying junk mails and text messages.
    13. In summary, advertising plays a vital role in thiscommercial world, which is a vivid and effective method of communicationand facilitates business activity and economic growth.
    14. Meanwhile, government authorities should enforcestricter standards on the advertising industry to avoid falseadvertising and misrepresentation, and protect the consumers' privacyand interests.

    6. So, when people start to wear stylish clothes likea superstar, they feel more confident and have higher self-esteem, whichis of course helpful and even essential in some social and businessoccasions
    7. Moreover, fashion is one element of popularculture.
    8. For example, entertainment celebrities share theirperspectives and outfits on social media.
    9. Being in fashion and following idols makes people understand andbecome more involved in popular culture and feel up-to-date in thisfast-changing world.
    10. This is not to say that everyone should befashion-conscious.
    11. Certainly, it is a personal choice to put oncomfortable clothes people are interested in.
    12. And since fashion changes over time, it would bebetter for people to pay more attention to something more meaningful inlife, like pursuing knowledge, loving family, and cherishingfriendship.
    13. In summary, fashion should be respected.
    14. Meanwhile, people should have their own tastes ofclothing style rather than blindly following the so-called"fashion".
    15. Only by doing so can we assure that fashion becomea means of self-expression rather than a mere trend to be followed.

    1. å¼•å…¥èƒŒæ™¯ï¼šAs global trade is becoming an irreversible trend, moreand more people are concerned about its pros and cons.
    2. äº¤ä»£è¾©è®ºè¯é¢˜ï¼šSome believe that it boosts economic development;while others point out that it is not an economical model becauseshipping costs and tariffs will result in nothing but a higher price ofa product that consumers would have to pay, and fuel consumed duringlong-distance transportation will contaminate the environment.
    3. è¡¨è¾¾å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ï¼šMy view is that global trade bringsus more good than harm.

    5. è¿›ä¸€æ­¥å…·ä½“é˜è¿°ç†ç”±ï¼Œæ‹“å±•ï¼šThis is because somecountries's economies depend heavily on exports, and in the meantime,other countries have to import raw material or products such as oil,steel and food from their neighbors.
    6. æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œè§‚ç‚¹æˆç«‹ï¼šSo, global trade benefits almostevery country and allows the world economy to be stable andprosperous.
    7. ç¬¬äºŒè®ºæ®ï¼Œä¸­å¿ƒå¥ï¼šMoreover, thanks to global trade,various imported goods have improved overall living standards.
    8. ä¸¾ä¾‹ï¼Œç»å…¸ä¸ªä¾‹æˆ–æ’æ¯”ä¾‹è¯ï¼šFor example, we aredriving cars manufactured in Germany, watching movies produced byHollywood, eating salmon imported from Japan, and wearing clothes madein China.
    9. ä¾‹è¯è§£é‡Šè¯´æ˜ï¼šWe cannot imagine what life would be like without suchgoods.
    10. è®¨è®ºåæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šIt is also true that global trade hascaused some problems.
    11. åæ–¹è®ºæ®ï¼šOf course, it may intensify commercialcompetition and long-distance shipping has negative impacts on theenvironment.
    12. é©³æ–¥åæ–¹æˆ–éƒ¨åˆ†åŒæ„åæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šBut, even if we couldban international trade, these problems would still exist, becausepeople may choose to travel abroad to purchase such products.
    13. é‡ç”³å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ï¼šIn summary, global trade offers awin-win situation for both importing and exporting countries.
    14. ä¸èƒ½å¿½è§†åæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šMeanwhile, I believe with thedevelopment of science and technology, we can eventually figure out someways to offset the drawbacks it has caused.
    15. æ€æƒ³ç«‹æ„æå‡ï¼šBy doing so we can make sure that thebenefits of global trade outweigh its limitations and contribute tosustainable economic growth and prosperity for nations worldwide.

    3. è¡¨è¾¾å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ï¼šMy view is that globalization not only boosts economicdevelopment, but generally has positive effects on nationalidentities.

    7. ç¬¬äºŒè®ºæ®ï¼Œä¸­å¿ƒå¥ï¼šMoreover, with globalized communication, nationalcultures and identities are more easily expressed to the outside worldand receive the respect and appreciation.
    8. ä¸¾ä¾‹ï¼Œç»å…¸ä¸ªä¾‹æˆ–æ’æ¯”ä¾‹è¯ï¼šFor example, the animated film "KungfuPanda", produced by Disney has become a [[blockbuster]] hit in manycountries.
    9. ä¾‹è¯è§£é‡Šè¯´æ˜ï¼šSince Kungfu and Panda are uniquely two Chineseelements, Chinese identity has been enhanced and has impressed manypeople around the world through this film.
    10. è®¨è®ºåæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šThose who harbor the view that cultural contacts maythreaten national identities may argue that now the younger generationsliving in Shanghai eat hamburgers, drink coffee, work in skyscrapers andeven speak English often, adapting a lifestyle similar to that of theirwestern counterparts.

    13. é‡ç”³å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ï¼šIn summary, increasing business and culture contactsdoes play an important role in country's development.
    14. ä¸èƒ½å¿½è§†åæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šMeanwhile, a more prosperous economy facilitatesthe recognition and reservation of national culture and identityworldwide.

    1. å¼•å…¥èƒŒæ™¯ï¼šChange occurs in every aspect of people's daily life,regardless of whether we want it to happen or not.
    2. äº¤ä»£è¾©è®ºè¯é¢˜ï¼šSome people do not like changes, mainly becausechanges bring unfamiliarity, which means the possibility of makingmistakes; others, however, believe change is always a good thing.
    3. è¡¨è¾¾å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ï¼šMy view is that the majority of changes lead topositive results, and we should adapt and keep pace with them.
    4. ç¬¬ä¸€è®ºæ®ï¼Œä¸­å¿ƒå¥ï¼šFirst, it is obvious that change, [[per se]] isthe only thing that never changes in the universe.
    5. è¿›ä¸€æ­¥å…·ä½“é˜è¿°ç†ç”±ï¼Œæ‹“å±•ï¼šThis means that although we may avoid ordeny some changes that could occur, we cannot stop the whole world fromchanging.
    6. æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œè§‚ç‚¹æˆç«‹ï¼šSo, it is wiser to face the reality, appreciatethese changes, and try to make the most of them.
    7. ç¬¬äºŒè®ºæ®ï¼Œä¸­å¿ƒå¥ï¼šMoreover, some changes like scientificinnovations, technological inventions, and new academic theories, aredriving forces behind social progress.
    8. ä¸¾ä¾‹ï¼Œç»å…¸ä¸ªä¾‹æˆ–æ’æ¯”ä¾‹è¯ï¼šFor example, modern information technologyhas already changed the world and the way people work, relax,communicate, and even receive education.
    9. ä¾‹è¯è§£é‡Šè¯´æ˜ï¼šIt has also improved the productivity of manyindustries as well as our living standard.
    10. è®¨è®ºåæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šThis is not to say that any changes end well.
    11. åæ–¹è®ºæ®ï¼šWhen we enjoy the benefits of changes, we sometimes losemore important things.
    12. é©³æ–¥åæ–¹æˆ–éƒ¨åˆ†åŒæ„åæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šIndeed, we have seen invaluabletraditional culture fade away, both people and animals have sufferedfrom climate change, and we are trying our best to protect theenvironment and ecosystem from negative changes.
    13. é‡ç”³å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ï¼šIn summary, most changes are an inevitable fact oflife and we had better develop an active attitude towards them.
    14. ä¸èƒ½å¿½è§†åæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼š
    15. æ€æƒ³ç«‹æ„æå‡ï¼šMeanwhile though, we have to preserve what we believeis valuable.

    1. ã€å¼•å…¥èƒŒæ™¯ã€‘Universities are one of the most important institutionsin modern society.
    2. ã€äº¤ä»£è¾©è®ºè¯é¢˜ã€‘ [[Post-secondary]] education provides both generalskills and knowledge and sometimes job-specific training. But which ofthese two should be the main focus?
    3. ã€è¡¨è¾¾å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ã€‘While many people might think the focus should onlybe "jobs", I believe universities play a larger social role.
    4. ã€ç¬¬ä¸€è®ºæ®ã€‘Let us consider that we live in an information age. If astudent wants to learn about accounting or history or other job-specificinformation, they do not need to sit in a classroom to get it.
    5. ã€è¿›ä¸€æ­¥å…·ä½“é˜è¿°ç†ç”±ï¼Œæ‰©å±•ã€‘Nowadays, anyone can get information andknowledge online and can learn on their own.
    6. ã€æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œè§‚ç‚¹æˆç«‹ã€‘So surely universities aren't needed for thispurpose.
    7. ã€ç¬¬äºŒè®ºæ®ï¼Œä¸­å¿ƒå¥ã€‘Instead, what universities should focus on isdeveloping [[critical thinking]].
    8. ã€è¿›ä¸€æ­¥å…·ä½“é˜è¿°ç†ç”±ï¼Œæ‰©å±•ã€‘Anyone can memorize facts andget on-job training, but not everyone can think and analyze.This is a far more important skill in the real world.
    9. ã€æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œè§‚ç‚¹æˆç«‹ã€‘To be able to process information, understand itand use it, these are the skills our universities should focus onbuilding.

    11. ã€åæ–¹è®ºæ®ã€‘Of course all graduates want to find good work.

And if you ask most employers what they are looking forin employees, they will tell you that it is a mind that can "[[thinkoutside of the box]]."
    13. ã€é‡ç”³å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ã€‘So while universities play a role intraining people for the [[workforce]], they primarily function as aplace for training the mind.ï¼ˆå¥½å¥ï¼‰
    14. ã€æ€æƒ³ç«‹æ„æå‡ã€‘What most companies and workforces need arenot robots, but creative people who can contribute ideas.(å¥½å¥)Universities should be the driving force in nurturing such people.

9.1.2 æ•™è‚²æ–¹æ³•

  1. è€ƒé¢˜
  2. æçº²

      1. åŸå›  1ï¼šæ•™å¸ˆæˆè¯¾çš„ä¼˜åŠ¿ï¼›

    1. å¼•å…¥èƒŒæ™¯ï¼šDistance learning is a relatively recent phenomenon andconsequently it is somewhat controversial.
    2. äº¤ä»£è¾©è®ºè¯é¢˜ï¼šWith good reason, many people question whethertechnology can really change how we can learn. Others, however, make aconvincing argument that classroom-based learning has itslimitations.
    3. è¡¨è¾¾å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ï¼šConsidering both sides, it is clear that thereis value in both approaches.
    4. ç¬¬ä¸€è®ºæ®ï¼šLet us first consider the pros of traditional,classroom-based learning.
    5. è¿›ä¸€æ­¥å…·ä½“é˜è¿°ç†ç”±ï¼Œæ‹“å±•ï¼šFrom the time of the ancient Greeks andChinese and perhaps before, we have clung to the idea of a "teacher",one who shares his / her wisdom and expertise. This model has beentested and survived the ages. Teachers not only can shareknowledge, but they can access, correct and motivatestudents.
    6. æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œè§‚ç‚¹æˆç«‹ï¼šTruly there is great value in this.
    7. ç¬¬äºŒè®ºæ®ï¼šThat said, remote learning also has its own upside.
    8. ä¸¾ä¾‹ï¼Œç»å…¸ä¸ªä¾‹æˆ–æ’æ¯”ä¾‹è¯ï¼šConsider, for example, students who livein remote areas without roads or funds to pay for tuition to attend aschool far away. An Internet connection solves this.
    9. æ’æ¯”ä¾‹è¯ï¼šAlso, there is something to be said for students beingmore independent learners, and online learning develops this skill.
    10. è®¨è®ºåæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šSo the question really is not "Which one?" butrather, "How we can combine both?"
    11. åæ–¹è®ºæ®ï¼šIt seems perfectly reasonable that students attend someclasses in person, but also use the web to communicate with otherstudents and professors as well as research various topics.
    12. é©³æ–¥åæ–¹æˆ–éƒ¨åˆ†åŒæ„åæ–¹è§‚ç‚¹ï¼šCountries and societies need to assesswhich approach and balance works best for them.
    13. é‡ç”³å†™ä½œè§‚ç‚¹ï¼šSo while we should harness the potential ofnew technology that makes remote learning possible, we should notneglect the importance of traditional learning.
    14. æ€æƒ³ç«‹æ„æå‡ï¼šStudents without teachers will surely be lost;but students who simply rely on teachers for knowledge are not reallylearning.
